original_content:

subject   : Subject: TAKING COMFORT IN HIS LEAD (6-2-20)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Mon, 1 Jun 2020 18:03:44 -0500
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):
===================================================================
*Today’s Verse:*

*They, **(the false teachers)** have lost connection with the **head, from
whom the whole body, is supported **and held together by its ligaments and
sinews, **grows as God causes it to grow. *(Col. 2:19)



*Today’s Reflection:*

We are all familiar with the image of the Christian community as the “body
of Christ.” Yet sometimes it’s easy for some to forget that their actions
affect the rest of the body. I have been sobered by the

realization of how the choices I make, can impact beyond myself. That is
when I take comfort in remembering that “Christ is the head.” Together, as
we follow His lead, we can form a body that looks upward in worship that
moves outward in service. *Ask Jesus for ways to work well with*

*other parts of His body today.*

* Pastor Sather*

May our words and actions build up the body, working together for Your glory. Guide us to serve one another and the world around us, that Your kingdom may come. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Christ made us right with God, He made us pure **and holy, and He freed us
from sin. *

(I Cor. 1:30)



*Today’s Reflection:*

God is our source and the reason for our personal relationship with Christ.
Our union and identification with Christ results in our having God’s wisdom
(Col. 2:3), being acceptable to God (2 Cor. 5:21), being pure (I Thess.
4:3-7), and having the

penalty for our sins paid by in full by Jesus (Mk. 10:35). *Thank Jesus for
being our Perfect Savior and **freeing us from sin.*

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:
God is our source and the reason for our personal relationship with Christ. Our union and identification with Christ results in our having God’s wisdom (Colossians 2:3), being acceptable to God (2 Corinthians 5:21), being pure (I Thessalonians 4:3-7), and having the
penalty for our sins paid by in full by Jesus (Mark 10:35). Thank Jesus for being our Perfect Savior and freeing us from sin.
original_verse_text: Christ made us right with God, He made us pure and holy, and He freed us from sin.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we praise You for the gift of Your Son, Jesus Christ, who has become our wisdom, righteousness, sanctification, and redemption. Through our union with Him, we have been reconciled to You and now stand in Your grace. We give thanks for the freedom from sin that You have provided through the sacrifice of Your perfect Son. May we ever cling to Christ, our Savior and Lord. Amen.
reflection: God is our source and the reason for our personal relationship with Christ. Our union and identification with Christ results in our having God’s wisdom (Colossians 2:3), being acceptable to God (2 Corinthians 5:21), being pure (I Thessalonians 4:3-7), and having the penalty for our sins paid by in full by Jesus (Mark 10:35). Thank Jesus for being our Perfect Savior and freeing us from sin.
subject: Our Perfect Savior
verse_text: Christ made us right with God, He made us pure and holy, and He freed us from sin.

subject   : Subject: A HOPEFUL FUTURE (6-4-20)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Wed, 3 Jun 2020 16:46:59 -0500
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):

*Today’s Verse:*

*I no longer live, but Christ lives in me. *(Gal. 2:20)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Because our sins died with Jesus, we are no longer condemned (Col.
2:13-15). In reality we have become one with Christ, and His experiences
are ours. Our Christ-ian life began when, in unity with Him

we died to our old life (see Ro. 6:5-11).

In our daily life we must crucify sinful desires that keep us from following
Christ. This, too, is a kind of dying with Him

(Lk. 9:23-25). And yet the focus of Christ-ianity is not dying but living.
But because we have been crucified with Christ, we have also been raised with
Him (Ro. 6:5). *We are no longer alone, for **Christ lives in us—He is our
power for living, **And *

*our hope for the future. *(Col. 1:27)

*Pastor Sather*

And yet the focus of Christ-ianity is not dying but living. But because we have been crucified with Christ, we have also been raised with Him (Romans 6:5). We are no longer alone, for Christ lives in us—He is our power for living, And our hope for the future. (Colossians 1:27)
original_verse_text: I no longer live, but Christ lives in me.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we thank You that through the death and resurrection of Your Son, Jesus, we have been crucified with Christ and are no longer condemned. Help us to daily put to death the sinful desires that keep us from following You, and to live in the power of the new life we have in Christ. May we find our hope and strength in the truth that Christ lives in us. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Give your burdens to the Lord, and He will take **care of you. He will not
let the godly to slip and **fall. *(Ps. 55:22) (NLT)



*Today’s Reflection:*

God wants us to give our burdens to Him, but often we continue to bear them
ourselves even when we say we are trusting Him. Trust the *same* strength

that sustains you to carry your cares also. Write today’s verse on a recipe
card. Now add Ps. 16:8 (NLT) beneath it*—“I know the Lord is always with
me. **I will not be* *shaken, for He is right beside.*

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:
God wants us to give our burdens to Him, but often we continue to bear them ourselves even when we say we are trusting Him. Trust the same strength
that sustains you to carry your cares also. Write today’s verse on a recipe card. Now add Psalm 16:8 (NLT) beneath it—“I know the Lord is always with me. I will not be shaken, for He is right beside.

prayer: Heavenly Father, we come to You with the burdens that weigh heavily upon our hearts. Forgive us for trying to carry these cares on our own, when You have promised to sustain us. Help us to truly cast our anxieties upon You, for You care for us. May we find rest in Your strength and the assurance that You are always with us, never to be shaken. In Your Son's name, we pray. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Jesus answered, “I am the way, and the truth, **and the life. No one can
come to the Father except **through me.” *(Jn. 14:6)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Jesus says He is the *Only way* to God the Father. Some people may argue
that this way is to narrow. In reality, it is wide enough for the whole
world, if the world chooses to accept it. As the *way*, Jesus is

our path to the Father. As the *truth*, He is the reality of all God
promises. As the *life*, He joins His divine life to ours, both now and for
eternity. Satan can only offer you things; nothing more. Jesus offers you

abundant life; life to it’s fullest (Jn. 10:10). *The life **Jesus offers
you has promises* *f**or both the present **life and the life to come* *(I
Tim. 4:8)*

* Pastor Sather*

We acknowledge that there is no other name under heaven given among men by which we must be saved (Acts 4:12). Help us to cling to the truth that Jesus alone is the path to eternal life with You. May we find in Him the abundant life that You have promised, both in this present age and in the life to come. We trust in Your Son, the only way to the Father. Amen.

*Today’s Verse;*

*There is now no condemnation for those who **are in Christ Jesus. *(Ro.
8:1)



*Today’s Reflection:*

“Not guilty, let him go free.” What would

those words mean to you if you were on

death row? The fact is that the whole human race is on death row, justly
condemned for repeatedly breaking God’s holy law. With out Jesus we would
have no hope at all. But thank God He has declared us not guilty and has
offered us freedom from sin and power to do His will. *Jesus’s intent is
always love.*

* Pastor Sather*

But thank God He has declared us not guilty and has offered us freedom from sin and power to do His will. Jesus’s intent is always love.

Fill us with Your Holy Spirit, that we may have the power to walk according to Your will and live in the freedom You have so graciously provided. May our lives reflect the love of Christ, who came to save the lost. Amen.

*Today’s Verses:*

*He will wipe every tear from their eyes, and there will** be no more death
or sorrow or crying or pain. All **these things are gone forever.” And the
one sitting **on the throne said, “Look, I am making everything
**new.” *(Rev.
21:4-5a)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Although there are many things I don’t fully understand in the book of
Revelation, I’m so glad it lets us know that one day we will witness the
ending we long for. Jesus will lead an army in the final battle to
eradicate evil. All things will be made

new. We will live with Jesus forever and

no longer experience suffering, heartache, pain or death. In the meantime,
when a problem arises, or things don’t seem to be working out, we need to
remember that’s

because “*. . .* it is not yet the end. Are you

dealing with problems? *Remind yourself* *that **all earthly things will
pass away.*

* Pastor Sather *

We take comfort in knowing that the Lamb in the center of the throne will be our shepherd, and He will guide us to springs of living water (Revelation 7:17). In the midst of our struggles, help us to fix our eyes on the eternal hope that awaits us in Your presence. May we find strength and peace in the assurance that all earthly things will pass away, and You will make all things new. Amen.

Today's Verse:

*Prove by the way you live that you have really t**urned from your sins and
turned to God. *(Mt. 3:8)



*Today’s Reflection:*

John the Baptist called people to more than

words or rituals; he told them to change their behavior. *“Prove by the way
you live that **you have really turned from your sins*” means that God
looks beyond words and religious activities to see if our conduct backs up
what we say, and He judges our words by our actions that accompany them. *Do
your actions **match your words.*

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:

words or rituals; he told them to change their behavior. “Prove by the way you live that you have really turned from your sins” means that God looks beyond words and religious activities to see if our conduct backs up what we say, and He judges our words by our actions that accompany them. Do your actions match your words.

May our deeds bear witness to the transformative power of Your grace, that others may see the reality of our relationship with You. Guide us, Lord, to walk in a manner worthy of the calling we have received. Amen.

*Subject: SAINTS IN WRONG PLACES *(6-10-20)



*Today’s Verses:*

*These events” happened as a warning to us, so that **we would not crave
evil things as they did, they were **written down to warn us, who live in a
time when **this **age *

*is drawing-to-a-close. *(I Cor. 10:6, 11b)



*Today’s Reflection:*

“t*hese events” *Is referring to the behavior of the Israelites who had
been led through the wilderness by the rock (Christ). Today’s pressures
make it easy to ignore or forget the lessons of the past. But Paul cautions
us to remember the lessons the

Israelites learned about God so we can avoid repeating their errors. The
key to remembering is to study the Bible regularly so that these lessons remind
us

of how God wants us to live. *We need*

*not repeat these mistakes.*

* Pastor Sather*

“these events” Is referring to the behavior of the Israelites who had been led through the wilderness by the rock (Christ). Today’s pressures make it easy to ignore or forget the lessons of the past. But Paul cautions us to remember the lessons the
Israelites learned about God so we can avoid repeating their errors. The key to remembering is to study the Bible regularly so that these lessons remind us of how God wants us to live. We need not repeat these mistakes.

prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with grateful hearts, acknowledging the lessons of the past that You have graciously preserved for us in Your Word. Help us to heed the warnings and examples found in the Scriptures, that we may not repeat the errors of those who have gone before us. Grant us the wisdom and discernment to walk faithfully in Your ways, keeping our eyes fixed on Jesus, the author and perfecter of our faith. May we be strengthened by the great cloud of witnesses who have run the race before us, and may we finish the course You have set before us with perseverance and joy. In Your Son's name we pray, Amen.

subject   : Subject: LOVE IS THE TOOL (6-11-20)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;

*Today's Verse: *
A voice cries: *"In the wilderness prepare the way*
*of the Lord. make straight in to desert a highway*
*for our God." *(Isa. 40:3)

*Today's Reflection:*
Preparing a straight, smooth road means, removing
obstacles and rolling out the red carpet for the com-
ing of the Lord. The desert is a picture of life's trials
and sufferings. We are not immune to those, but our
faith need not be hindered by them, Isaiah told people to prepare to see
God's work. John the
Baptist used these words as he challenged the
people to prepare for the coming Messiah (Mt. 3:3).
*When it comes to growth and change, love*
*prepares the way.*
* Pastor Sather*

John the Baptist used these words as he challenged the people to prepare for the coming Messiah (Matthew 3:3). When it comes to growth and change, love prepares the way.

Just as John the Baptist called the people to make straight paths, may we remove the obstacles and smooth the way for Your work in our lives. In the midst of life's trials and sufferings, may our faith remain steadfast, trusting in Your redeeming love. Lord, help us to be vessels of Your grace, rolling out the red carpet for the Messiah, that all may see Your salvation. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Your people will rebuild the ancient ruins and **will raise up the age-old
foundations; you will **be called Repairer of Broken Walls, Restorers **of
Streets with Dwellings. * (Isa. 58:12)



*Today’s Reflection:*

We cannot be saved without faith in Christ, but our faith lacks sincerity
if it does not reach out to others. Fasting can be bene-

ficial spiritually and physically, but at its best fasting helps only the
person during it. God says He wants our fasting to go beyond our own
personal growth to acts of kindness, charity, justice, and generosity.

*This truly is pleasing to God.*

* Pastor Sather*

prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You, acknowledging that our faith must be accompanied by compassionate acts of love and service. Help us to be those who "repair the breach and restore streets to live in," as Your prophet Isaiah declared. May our fasting and spiritual disciplines lead us to care for the poor, the oppressed, and the marginalized in our communities. Empower us by Your Spirit to be doers of Your Word, not just hearers alone. In Christ's name we pray, Amen.
reflection: We cannot be saved without faith in Christ, but our faith lacks sincerity if it does not reach out to others. Fasting can be beneficial spiritually and physically, but at its best fasting helps only the person during it. God says He wants our fasting to go beyond our own personal growth to acts of kindness, charity, justice, and generosity. This truly is pleasing to God.
subject: Ask Jesus to Renovate Your Heat
verse_text: Your people will rebuild the ancient ruins and will raise up the age-old foundations; you will be called Repairer of Broken Walls, Restorers of Streets with Dwellings.

*Today’s Verse:*

*And I heard a sound from heaven like the roar of** rushing waters and like
the peal *

*of thunder. The** sound I heard was like that of harpists playing **their
harps. *(Rev. 14:2)



*Today’s Reflection:*

While waterfalls can provide a measure of power and electricity we know
that Jesus is mightier than the waters He created. All of nature is merely
a limited expression of His supreme majesty, and here is some good news.
Nobody has to go on vacation

to see the natural wonder of Lord’s glory.

We see Him in the stars, a rose petal, and

a butterfly. *We see the Lord’s face* *in the mor**ning sun.*

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:
While waterfalls can provide a measure of power and electricity we know that Jesus is mightier than the waters He created. All of nature is merely a limited expression of His supreme majesty, and here is some good news. Nobody has to go on vacation to see the natural wonder of Lord’s glory. We see Him in the stars, a rose petal, and
a butterfly. We see the Lord’s face in the morning sun.
original_verse_text:
And I heard a sound from heaven like the roar of rushing waters and like the peal  of thunder.
The sound I heard was like that of harpists playing their harps.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we stand in awe of Your magnificent creation, which declares Your glory and the work of Your hands. From the thunderous roar of the waterfall to the delicate beauty of a butterfly, we see reflections of Your power and artistry. May we never take for granted the wonders that surround us, but instead, lift our eyes to the heavens and behold Your splendor. Lord, open our hearts to perceive Your presence in the everyday, that we may worship You with grateful and reverent hearts. Amen.

All of nature is merely a limited expression of His supreme majesty, and here is some good news. Nobody has to go on vacation to see the natural wonder of the Lord's glory. * (*6-14-20)

*Today’s Verses:*

*But when he (David) looked around at the high waves, he **was terrified
and began to sink. “Save me Lord!” he shouted.*

*Instantly Jesus reached out His hand and grabbed him. “You **Don’t have
much faith.” Jesus said. “Why did you doubt me.” *(Mt. 14:30-31)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Even though we start out with good intentions, sometimes our faith falters.
This doesn’t mean we have failed. When

Peter’s faith faltered, he reached out to Christ, the only one who could
help. He was afraid but he still looked to Christ.

When you are apprehensive about the troubles around and doubt Christ’s
presence or ability to help, remember that He is always with you and
is the *only
one*

who can really help. *Don’t look at the storms of life, **but look to Jesus
and He will rescue you. *

* Pastor Sather*

*Today's Verse:*
*For we do not have a High priest who is unable*
*to empathize with our weakness, but we have*
*One who has been tempted in every way, just*
*as we are--yet he did not sin. (Heb. 4:15)

*Today's Reflection:*
Jesus like us was tempted, but when He was
tempted in the desert by the devil He fought
back by speaking the word itself. We can be
comforted knowing that Jesus faced temptations
so He can sympathize with us. We can draw
encouraged from the fact that He did not fall
into sin. By His life he shows us that we to don't
have to sin when facing the seductive lure of
temptation. Remember Jesus is the only perfect
human being who has ever lived. *Ask Jesus to*
*direct you to Scriptures when you are tempted*
*Then prepare for the victory.*
* Pastor Sather*

May we find comfort in the knowledge that Jesus understands our struggles and intercedes on our behalf. Amen.

*Today’s Verses:*

*Remember, no one who wants to do wrong should **ever say, “God is tempting
me.” God is never **tempted to do wrong, and He never tempts anyone **else
either. *(14) *Temptation comes from the lure of **our *

*own **desires.* (brought about by Satan)



*Today’s Reflection:*

This is why I have to confess that I have a problem with the Lord’s Prayer!
I can no longer pray “*lead**us not** into temptation.” *I now pray, “*Do
not allow us** be led into temptation by Satin.” *I do believe a lot

of people who live for God often wonder why they still have temptations.
Does God tempt them? God tests people, *but* He does not tempt them by trying
to seduce them to sin. However, God, does allow Satin to tempt people, in
order to refine

their faith and to help them grow in their dependence upon Christ. *We can
resist the temptation **to sin by turning to God for strength and **by
choosing to obey His Word.*

* Pastor Sather*

Does God tempt them? God tests people, but He does not tempt them by trying to seduce them to sin. However, God, does allow Satin to tempt people, in order to refine
their faith and to help them grow in their dependence upon Christ. We can resist the temptation to sin by turning to God for strength and by choosing to obey His Word.

Help us to resist the devil, drawing near to You for the strength to stand firm in our faith. May our trials refine us and deepen our dependence on Christ, that we may walk in obedience to Your Word. In Your name we pray, Amen.
reflection: This is why I have to confess that I have a problem with the Lord's Prayer! I can no longer pray "lead us not into temptation." I now pray, "Do not allow us to be led into temptation by Satan." I do believe a lot of people who live for God often wonder why they still have temptations. Does God tempt them? God tests people, but He does not tempt them by trying to seduce them to sin. However, God does allow Satan to tempt people, in order to refine their faith and to help them grow in their dependence upon Christ. *Today’s Verse:*

*God blesses those who mourn, for they will be **comforted. *(Mt 5:4)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Jesus began His sermon with words that seem to contradict each other. But
God’s way of living usually contradicts the world's. If you want to live
for God, you must be ready to say and do what seems strange to the world.
You must be willing

to give when others take, to love when

others hate, to help when others abuse. By

giving up your own rights in order to save

others, *you will one day receive every-thing **God has instore for you.*

* Pastor Sather*

As we reflect on the words of Jesus, we are reminded that Your kingdom operates in ways that seem contrary to the world's wisdom. Help us to mourn with those who mourn, to weep with those who weep, and to sacrificially love even when it is difficult. Grant us the courage to give up our own rights for the sake of others, trusting that in doing so, we will one day receive the fullness of the blessings You have in store. May we be faithful to Your call, even when it seems strange to the world. Amen.

By giving up your own rights in order to save others, you will one day receive everything God has in store for you.

*Today’s Verses:*

*When the Devil had finished tempting Jesus, he **left Him until the next
oppor-tunity. * (Lk. 4:13)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Christ’s defeat of the Devil in the wilder-ness was decisive *but* not
final. Through-out His ministry, Jesus would confront Satan in many forms. Many
people mis-takenly see temptation as something

that will plague them one time. In reality, we all need to be constantly on
guard against the Devil’s ongoing attacks. Where are you most susceptible to
temptation right now? *How are you preparing*

*to withstand it?*

* Pastor Sather*

*Today’s Verse:*

*The seed that fell on good soil are those who hear **the Word and commit
themselves to it with a good **and upright heart. *

(Lk. 8:15)



*Today’s Reflection:*

I love the end of this parable, about those who respond to Jesus’s
invitation to follow Him. They “commit themselves to [the Word] with a good
and upright heart. Through their resolve, they bear fruit”. There are four
types of soil in this parable; *hard path—rocky soil—thorny **ground—good
soil*. Read verses 11—15 then

honestly evaluate your life. *If you think your **life is represented in
verse 15, you must be **truly committed to God’s Word.*

* Pastor Sather*

May we not merely hear Your Word, but be doers of it, committing ourselves fully to the path You have set before us. Guide us, Lord, to live out our faith with unwavering resolve, that we may bring glory to Your name. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Jesus is the same yesterday, today, and forever. *(Heb. 13:8)



*Today’s Reflection:*

How many times have you heard promises made by human leaders that never
delivered on their promise? Oh yes there are many human leaders that have
good

intensions, but it is Christ that we should,

choose as our ultimate leader. Unlike any human leaders He will never
change. Christ has been and will be the same

forever. *In a changing world we can trust **our unchanging Lord.*

* Pastor Sather*

intentions, but it is Christ that we should,
choose as our ultimate leader. Unlike any human leaders He will never change. Christ has been and will be the same forever. In a changing world we can trust our unchanging Lord.

prayer: Heavenly Father, we praise You for Your steadfast love and unwavering faithfulness. We thank You for Your enduring presence and the security we have in Your unchanging nature. Amen.
reflection: In a changing world, we can trust our unchanging Lord.

*Today’s Verse:*

*The eternal God is our refuge, and His everlasting a**rms are under you.
He thrusts out the enemy before **you; it is He who cries, ‘Destroy them!’
*(Deut. 33:27)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Moses’ song declares that God is our refuge, our only true security. How
often we trust our lives to other things—it might be money, career, a noble
cause, or a

lifelong dream. But our only true refuge is the eternal God, who always
holds out His arms to catch us when, the shaky supports that we trust
collapse and we fall. No storm can destroy us when we take refuge

in Him. Those without God, however, must forever be cautious. One mistake
may wipe them out. Living for God in

this world, may look like risky business. *But it is the godless who are
on **shaky *

*ground.* *Because God is our refuge, **we *

*can dare to be bold.*

* Pastor Sather*

message_id: 172de1c6f8b0ea82
subject   : Subject: QUALIFICATION TO FOLLOW CHRIST (6-23-20)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Mon, 22 Jun 2020 17:18:25 -0500

*Today’s Verse:*

*Instead we will hold to the truth in love, becoming **more and more in
every way like Christ, who is the **head of His body the church. Under His
direction,** the whole body is held together perfectly.*

(Eph. 4:15-16b)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Christ is the truth (Jn. 14:6) and the Holy Spirit, who guides the church,
is the Spirit of truth (Jn. 16:13). Satan, by contrast, is the Father of
lies (Jn. 8:14). As followers of Christ, we must be committed to the
truth. This
means that our words should be honest and that our actions should reflect
Christ’s integrity. Holding to the truth is not always easy, convenient, or
pleasant, but it is necessary if the church is going to do Christ’s work in
the world. *Some*

*Christ**ians fear that any mistake will destroy their witness **for the
Lord.*
* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:
Christ is the truth (John 14:6) and the Holy Spirit, who guides the church, is the Spirit of truth (John 16:13). Satan, by contrast, is the Father of lies (John 8:14). As followers of Christ, we must be committed to the truth. This means that our words should be honest and that our actions should reflect Christ’s integrity.
Holding to the truth is not always easy, convenient, or pleasant, but it is necessary if the church is going to do Christ’s work in the world. Some Christians fear that any mistake will destroy their witness for the Lord.
original_verse_text: Instead we will hold to the truth in love, becoming more and more in every way like Christ, who is the head of His body the church. Under His direction, the whole body is held together perfectly.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You, seeking to walk in the truth as revealed in Your Son, Jesus Christ. Help us to put off the old self and its deceptive ways, and to be renewed in the spirit of our minds, that we may reflect the image of our Creator. Grant us the courage to speak and act with integrity, even when it is difficult, that we may be a light to the world and build up the body of Christ. May our words and deeds be pleasing in Your sight. Amen.
reflection: Christ is the truth (John 14:6), and the Holy Spirit, who guides the church, is the Spirit of truth (John 16:13). Satan, by contrast, is the Father of lies (John 8:44). As followers of Christ, we must be committed to the truth. This means that our words should be honest and that our actions should reflect Christ's integrity. Holding to the truth is not always easy, convenient, or pleasant, but it is necessary if the church is going to do Christ's work in the world. Some Christians fear that any mistake will destroy their witness for the Lord.
subject: Qualification to Follow Christ
verse_text: Instead we will hold to the truth in love, becoming more and more in every way like Christ, who is the head of His body the church. Under His direction, the whole body is held together perfectly.

(6-24-20)



*Today’s Verse:*

*At dawn Jesus was standing on the beach, but **the disciples couldn’t
recognize who He was.* (Jn. 21:4)



*Today’s Reflection:*

The Bible describes Christ love for us as being deeper than the ocean. The
beach proclaims His majesty. His presence and the depth of His love. Let
the vastness of the ocean and the beauty of His creation remind you again
today that His love for you is fathomless. *Remind yourself of*

*the amazing depths of His love that He has **for you and praise Him.*
*Pastor Sather*

Your creation proclaims Your majesty and the unfathomable depths of Your affection for us. May we be rooted and grounded in the boundless love of Christ, that we may know the breadth, length, height, and depth of Your love that surpasses all understanding. We praise You for the immeasurable riches of Your grace and the immense love that You have lavished upon us. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*The Lord Himself goes before you and will be with **you, He will never
leave you or forsake you. Do not** be afraid; do not be discouraged. *(Deut.
31:8)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Why do we become discouraged, and forsake God? Often it is because we (like
a tree) have began to rot on the inside. The deterioration may have started
with a little white lie or a small drink or forsak-

ing the assembly to go fishing or camping. Long before our feet carry us
where we should not go, and our hands do what they

ought not do, the desire is in our hearts (Ps. 119:9-11).

With a pure heart we will be able to stand the stress of temptation and
overcome discouragement. *Remember **He will*

*never leave you or forsake you!*

* Pastor Sather*

Help us to keep our hearts pure, rooted in Your Word, that we may stand firm against the temptations that seek to draw us away. Lord, may we remember Your promise to never leave or forsake us, and may Your strength and courage be our constant guide. We trust in Your unwavering love and faithfulness. Amen.

message_id: 172ed94f2d353e35
subject   : Subject: HE NEVER STOPS LOVING US (6-26-20)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Thu, 25 Jun 2020 17:24:21 -0500
===================================================================

*Today’s Verse:*

*Jesus said, “Let the little children come to Me, and do **not hinder them,
for the kingdom of heaven belongs to **such as these.” *(Mt. 19:14)



*Today’s Reflection:*

A minister was retiring, and had delivered his last sermon from the pulpit
where he had preached for many years. One of the faithful members stopped
as she went out the door

and asked, “Do you know what is the most important thing you said in all
these years?” “What was that?” the minster inquired, so he might learn of
one way he had helped some-

one. “You told us we cannot do anything to

get God to stop loving us!” was the quiet reply. The most important thing that
you can learn in life is that God never stops loving you!

--*Peter *lied about being one of the disciples, but God loved him (Mt.
26:70).

--*The mothers and their small children *were a problem for the disciples,
but God loved them (Mt. 19:14).

--*The woman* refused to give Jesus a drink of water from the well, but God
loved her

(Jn. 4:9).

No matter what your life has been like, He still loves you! *How much do
you love God?*

* Pastor Sather*

===================================================================

*Today’s Verse:*

*For He is our peace (*Eph.2:14)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Among the students at a college was a young man on crutches. Although not a
handsome fellow, he had a talent for friendliness and optimism, and he
earned

many scholastic honors as well as the respect of his classmates.

One day a new student asked him what had caused him to become so badly
crippled. “Infantile paralysis,” replied

the young man. “With a misfortune like that,” exclaimed the new student,
“How can you face the world so confidently

and so happily?” “OH” replied the polio victim, “*The disease never
touched my **heart*.”

*Pastor Sather*

*Sorry about the delay I spent the night in the *

*hospital.*
original_reflection_text:
Among the students at a college was a young man on crutches.
Although not a handsome fellow, he had a talent for friendliness and optimism, and he earned
many scholastic honors as well as the respect of his classmates.
One day a new student asked him what had caused him to become so badly crippled. “Infantile paralysis,” replied the young man. “With a misfortune like that,” exclaimed the new student, “How can you face the world so confidently and so happily?” “OH” replied the polio victim, “The disease never touched my heart .”
original_verse_text: For He is our peace.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with grateful hearts, for You have granted us the peace that surpasses all understanding (Philippians 4:7). Even in the face of adversity and physical challenges, may we, like the young man in the reflection, find our strength and confidence in You. Lord, help us to remember that our true worth is not found in our outward appearance or circumstances, but in the condition of our hearts, which You have reconciled to Yourself through the sacrifice of Your Son, our Lord Jesus Christ (Ephesians 2:14). May we, too, face the world with the same unwavering faith and optimism, knowing that Your love and grace are sufficient for us. Amen.

subject   : Subject: LET GOD BE THE JUDGE (6-28-20)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Sat, 27 Jun 2020 18:13:36 -0500
===================================================================

*Today’s Verse:*

*When the disciples James and John saw this, they said, “Lord** do you want
us to call fire down from heaven to consume them? *(Lk. 9:54)



*Today’s Reflection:*

When James and John were rejected by the Samaritan village, they didn’t
want

to stop at shaking the dust off their feet

(Lk. 9:5). They wanted to retaliate by calling down fire from heaven on the
people, as Elijah did on the servants of

a wicked king of Israel (2 Kg. 1). When others reject or scorn us, we, too,
may

feel like retaliating. But let us remember that judgement belongs to God. *We
must not expect Him to use His power **to carry out our personal vendettas.*

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text: When James and John were rejected by the Samaritan village, they didn’t want to stop at shaking the dust off their feet (Luke 9:5). They wanted to retaliate by calling down fire from heaven on the people, as Elijah did on the servants of a wicked king of Israel (2 Kg. 1). When others reject or scorn us, we, too, may feel like retaliating. But let us remember that judgment belongs to God. We must not expect Him to use His power to carry out our personal vendettas.
original_verse_text: When the disciples James and John saw this, they said, “Lord do you want us to call fire down from heaven to consume them?
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with humble hearts, acknowledging that judgment belongs to You alone. When we face rejection or scorn, help us to resist the temptation to retaliate or call down Your wrath upon our enemies. Instead, grant us the grace to love our enemies, bless those who curse us, and pray for those who mistreat us, as Your Son Jesus taught. May we reflect Your compassion and mercy, even in the face of adversity. We trust in Your perfect justice and timing. Amen.
reflection: When James and John were rejected by the Samaritan village, they didn't want to stop at shaking the dust off their feet (Luke 9:5). They wanted to retaliate by calling down fire from heaven on the people, as Elijah did on the servants of a wicked king of Israel (2 Kg. 1). When others reject or scorn us, we, too, may feel like retaliating. But let us remember that judgment belongs to God. We must not expect Him to use His power to carry out our personal vendettas.

subject   : Subject: ACCEPTING OUR YEARS (6-29-20)

*Today’s Verse:*

*The strength of those who wait with hope in the Lord **will be renewed.
They will run and won’t become weary. **They will walk and won’t grow
tired. *(40:31)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Experience is a good teacher. We are confident that: They who wait for the
Lord shall renew their strength, they

shall mount up with wings like eagles.

They shall run and not grow weary, they shall walk and not faint.

When it is put like that, it is easy to see the advantage of growing
older rather than shrinking younger. In the spiritual realm, *who would
want *his faith to grow

weaker day by day? Who would want to see his Christlike qualities diminish
with the passing of time? Who would want

to give up the personal experiences where

God has proven his faithfulness time and again in one’s own life? *Not Me!*

* Pastor Al*

Who would want to see his Christlike qualities diminish with the passing of time? Who would want to give up the personal experiences where
God has proven his faithfulness time and again in one’s own life? Not Me!

prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with grateful hearts, reflecting on the promises found in Your Word. Like the eagle that soars high, may our faith in You grow stronger with each passing day. Help us to press on, forgetting what lies behind and straining forward to what is ahead, that we may run the race of life without growing weary or fainting. Lord, renew our strength and empower us to walk in Your ways, that our lives may bring glory to Your name. Amen.

*The Lord is our light and our protector. He gives **us grace and glory. No
good thing will the Lord **withhold from those who do what is right. *(Ps.
84:11)



*Today’s Reflection:*

God does not promise to give us every-

thing we think is good, but He will not withhold what is permanently good.
He will give us the means to walk along His paths, but we must do the walk
ing.

*When we obey Him, He will not hold any**thing* *back that will help us
serve Him.*

* Pastor Sather *

*Today’s Verse:*

*May these words of my mouth and the meditation of my **heart be pleasing
in your sight, Lord, my Rock and my *

*Redeemer. *(Ps. 19:14) 


*Today’s Reflection:*

Would you change the way you live *if* you knew that every word and thought
would be examined by God first? David asks that God approve his words and
thoughts

as though they were offerings brought to the alter. As you begin each day,
pray that God’s love will guide what you say and what you think.

*Father, let the words of my mouth (or even an email) **be used to
encourage others.*

* Pastor Sather *
